blog.name: snarkyfinch
blog.title: Cowardice and Spite
blog.description: Welcome to Hell. Icon by tumblr user ufosonmyroof  ^o^ Requests are: Open!

question: Crowley and Aziraphale’s first kiss?
answer:
When Aziraphale wanders to his small kitchen that morning there are many things he expects to see and on thing he doesn’t expect at all. Of course, with his very odd luck, that one thing is what he finds waiting for him as he shuffles in in nothing more than a robe. Today was going to be a relaxing day off, that’s what he’d planned for.
He hadn’t planned for a visitor.

He certainly hadn’t planned for the visitor to be Crowley.

The demon, to his credit, looks somewhat apologetic as Aziraphale stares in mute shock at him. “Hello, angel,” he greets, something in his tone telling Zira that this is more than one of the demon’s usual drop ins. There’s meaning to this, and he’s left hoping it’s something good. He could do with something good, these days.
“Sorry to drop in like this. I hadn’t planned to, it’s just- well- it’s silly is what it is.” Crowley turns his face away and Aziraphale is very suddenly struck with the realization that Crowley looks distinctly thinner than he usually does.
“Are you alright?”

For all his claims of not being Crowley’s friend over the years, he knows all too well how untrue it is. If anything he’s Crowley’s best friend, and Crowley is his.
If anything, really, he loves the demon but he won’t ever admit that. Ever.

Maybe.

“No, angel, I don’t believe I really am. Right now, at least. I made cocoa. Or tried to. I’m still not as good as you are at making it.” Crowley offers a mug that Zira is happy to accept, taking a few testing sips and very nearly groaning at the flavor that graces his lips.
“Perfect,” he mumbles into his mug, trying very hard not to blush at the fond look Crowley gives him.
“Glad you think so.” Crowley hums, leaning back on the counter with a mug of his own cocoa in hand.

There’s a silence, and at first Zira dreads over having to be the one to break it. Then, Crowley speaks. “I’d like to stay here with you, for a while. If I could.” He doesn’t explain why, what’s happened, anything, but then again he never really has gone into detail when he’s in need. He’s embarrassed about it, Zira thinks.
“You’re welcome to stay, dear. I’ve got a spare room and everything.” Zira makes sure he sounds happy to have Crowley staying (not that he isn’t, he just has to make it pronounced so the demon will hear it and believe it), smiling as widely as he can without it looking forced. Crowley returns the smile with his own little gentle smile, and while his eyes remain hidden behind his glasses Zira knows they’re glowing.

“Thank you, Aziraphale.” As always, it’s odd to hear the name roll off the demon’s tongue. Roll it does, though, and Aziraphale decides he’d quite like to hear it more often. He’d never want Crowley to stop saying angel, though. He’s grown quite attached to the endearment over the years.
“Anything for you, dearest.” Zira says it all too sincerely and suddenly Crowley looks almost distraught before his face melts into something more relaxed once more.

“Angel?”
“Yes, dear?”
“May I do something a bit bold?”
“Always, Crowley.”

Aziraphale has an idea of what’s coming as Crowley sets aside his cocoa and his glasses, as the demon takes a hesitant step into the angel’s space. Aziraphale sets his own mug down in response, nodding encouragingly when he catches Crowley’s hands nervously twitching at his sides.

Crowley finally reaches out to take Aziraphale’s face in his hands, looking as though he has just gotten his hands on something extremely precious. Then, in a moment that seems to last hours, he leans in and presses his lips to Zira’s. It is not a harsh kiss, it is not wanting or lusty or desperate. It’s gentle and loving, everything he had heard demon’s were incapable of.

It is not Crowley asking for something more, this isn’t a door opening to a day spent copulating like wild animals.
This is Crowley’s confession, his love stated in one gesture because he has never been good with words. Not where emotions are concerned.

Zira melts into him, pressing close and returning the kiss with the gentle gusto he needs to to make Crowley understand his answer.

I’m yours, darling. I’m yours.

blog.name: forineffablereasons
blog.title: quite the vintage
blog.description: darcy. main @watsonshoneybee

summary: crowley’s not really big on speaking. that’s not entirely true: crowley loves to talk. he talks about documentaries he watched...
body:
crowley’s not really big on speaking.

that’s not entirely true: crowley loves to talk. he talks about documentaries he watched on telly and magazines articles printed on the slick paper aziraphale hates. he talks about silly things he saw people doing while stuck in traffic and the new hairstyles he’s been seeing on this or that red carpet. he talks with aziraphale all the time, more than anyone else, obviously: discussion and debate and what are you up to and so on.

but biting your tongue is a difficult habit to break, and crowley’s been biting his for so long that sometimes aziraphale wonders if he’s never bitten it straight through. 

it’s fine. aziraphale has learned to read the things that matter off of crowley’s face, out of his hands, so long ago, he doesn’t need them said, and if he repays crowleys’s six thousand years of patience with six thousand of his own, well. aziraphale would wait to the end of the world, and after it too.

which means he’s not expecting it when crowley slips up behind him in bed one morning and noses into the back of his neck and says, so very quietly, you know i love you, right?

aziraphale can’t help the way all the breath whooshes out of him, the way he collapses back into crowley: it’s automatic, a moth to a flame. his heart, lazy with sleep and lack of necessity, kicks into double-time, and crowley’s arm comes around him; his mouth is warm on aziraphale’s shoulder.

i’ve always known, aziraphale says. crowley huffs a laugh in his ear: disbelieving. oh, all right, it took me a while to realise what it was. or why it was. but i did know it.

crowley’s mouth slips into a grin against aziraphale’s skin. a while, he repeats. six thousand years is a good bit longer than a while. 

don’t be ridiculous, aziraphale shoots back, elbowing crowley in the ribs. then he leans back further, sinking into crowley’s hold; crowley pulls him in. it was only five thousand nine hundred and forty-one.

blog.name: drawn-and-talk-of-peace
blog.title: I hate the word, as I hate Hell, all Montagues...
blog.description:
... and thee. Hey, everyone! I'm Hannah, I'm 20, I'm into a lot of fandoms, and as you can see, I adore Shakespeare. 
Ko-Fi page

summary: I got into Good Omens about 6 years ago (6, maybe 5). Read the book in a day or two and immediately found comfort and delight in...
body:
I got into Good Omens about 6 years ago (6, maybe 5). Read the book in a day or two and immediately found comfort and delight in obsessing over it. I loved the easy humor, the depth and thought put into it by @neil-gaiman and Terry Pratchett, the plot, the characters—everything.

And you know what else I loved? The unconditional love and care shown by Crowley and Aziraphale in the face of their differences as a demon and an angel. I found something like safety in reading about them, and that feeling of safety was something I desperately needed when I was fourteen, bullied, isolated, and depressed. The fandom on tumblr was relatively small, but it didn’t matter to me. I was just glad there were others who loved the book as much as I did, even though I was too afraid to ever reach out to anyone.

And I’ll admit it—I was terrified to hear about the show. I’d never seen Michael Sheen in anything and I wasn’t 100% sure that David Tennant would be a good Crowley. I am so glad I took the chance and watched it, though, because the two of them ARE Crowley and Aziraphale. It didn’t matter that they were a little different from the picture in my head, because they breathed life into characters who made my life a little less hellish when I was ready to throw in the towel. And I’m part of the LGBT community, which kids bullied me for, too. So to see Aziraphale look at Crowley with such open, unabashed adoration meant the world to me. I felt safe again with those characters and I can never thank anyone enough for that. I’ve cried enough while writing this already, but the gratitude and love I have for Good Omens is endless. Not to sound like a dramatic teenager on her balcony in Verona, but the love I feel for Good Omens is infinite and difficult to describe. One might even call it “ineffable.” So… I guess this was all a long, tearful, and convoluted way to express the way these characters and this story have helped me. I can never, ever say “thank you” enough.

And I’m part of the LGBT community, which kids bullied me for, too. So to see Aziraphale look at Crowley with such open, unabashed adoration meant the world to me. I felt safe again with those characters and I can never thank anyone enough for that. I’ve cried enough while writing this already, but the gratitude and love I have for Good Omens is endless. Not to sound like a dramatic teenager on her balcony in Verona, but the love I feel for Good Omens is infinite and difficult to describe. One might even call it “ineffable.” So… I guess this was all a long, tearful, and convoluted way to express the way these characters and this story have helped me. I can never, ever say “thank you” enough.

trail.content_raw:
I got into Good Omens about 6 years ago (6, maybe 5). Read the book in a day or two and immediately found comfort and delight in obsessing over it. I loved the easy humor, the depth and thought put into it by @neil-gaiman and Terry Pratchett, the plot, the characters—everything.

And you know what else I loved? The unconditional love and care shown by Crowley and Aziraphale in the face of their differences as a demon and an angel. I found something like safety in reading about them, and that feeling of safety was something I desperately needed when I was fourteen, bullied, isolated, and depressed. The fandom on tumblr was relatively small, but it didn’t matter to me. I was just glad there were others who loved the book as much as I did, even though I was too afraid to ever reach out to anyone.

And I’ll admit it—I was terrified to hear about the show. I’d never seen Michael Sheen in anything and I wasn’t 100% sure that David Tennant would be a good Crowley. I am so glad I took the chance and watched it, though, because the two of them ARE Crowley and Aziraphale. It didn’t matter that they were a little different from the picture in my head, because they breathed life into characters who made my life a little less hellish when I was ready to throw in the towel. And I’m part of the LGBT community, which kids bullied me for, too. So to see Aziraphale look at Crowley with such open, unabashed adoration meant the world to me. I felt safe again with those characters and I can never thank anyone enough for that. I’ve cried enough while writing this already, but the gratitude and love I have for Good Omens is endless. Not to sound like a dramatic teenager on her balcony in Verona, but the love I feel for Good Omens is infinite and difficult to describe. One might even call it “ineffable.” So… I guess this was all a long, tearful, and convoluted way to express the way these characters and this story have helped me. I can never, ever say “thank you” enough.
trail.content:
I got into Good Omens about 6 years ago (6, maybe 5). Read the book in a day or two and immediately found comfort and delight in obsessing over it. I loved the easy humor, the depth and thought put into it by @neil-gaiman and Terry Pratchett, the plot, the characters—everything.

And you know what else I loved? The unconditional love and care shown by Crowley and Aziraphale in the face of their differences as a demon and an angel. I found something like safety in reading about them, and that feeling of safety was something I desperately needed when I was fourteen, bullied, isolated, and depressed. The fandom on tumblr was relatively small, but it didn’t matter to me. I was just glad there were others who loved the book as much as I did, even though I was too afraid to ever reach out to anyone.

And I’ll admit it—I was terrified to hear about the show. I’d never seen Michael Sheen in anything and I wasn’t 100% sure that David Tennant would be a good Crowley. I am so glad I took the chance and watched it, though, because the two of them ARE Crowley and Aziraphale. It didn’t matter that they were a little different from the picture in my head, because they breathed life into characters who made my life a little less hellish when I was ready to throw in the towel. And I’m part of the LGBT community, which kids bullied me for, too. So to see Aziraphale look at Crowley with such open, unabashed adoration meant the world to me. I felt safe again with those characters and I can never thank anyone enough for that. I’ve cried enough while writing this already, but the gratitude and love I have for Good Omens is endless. Not to sound like a dramatic teenager on her balcony in Verona, but the love I feel for Good Omens is infinite and difficult to describe. karasusama replied to your post:

body:
karasusama replied to your post: This whole ‘Aziraphale only realising he loves…
For me, Aziraphale has known he was in love with Crowley during a long time but during the scene in the church is when he accepts his feelings for him.

For me, it was him realising that loving Crowley is a good thing, because he’s actually good.

It should also be said that I’ve considered them as being awkwardly in love since 1020

summary: Is it possible that so many people are choosing to interpret Aziraphale and Crowley’s relationship as simply “best friends”?...
body: Is it possible that so many people are choosing to interpret Aziraphale and Crowley’s relationship as simply “best friends”? I’ve gotten several comments on posts here and on my fics on AO3 from people who are referring to them as “BFFs” and “best friends” and “friends.” Like, are these people joking, or do they really not see it?

tags: maybe? rather be safe than sorry
summary:
the last scene with Crowley and Aziraphale? Beautiful. A masterpiece. Literal poetic cinema. 
“I like to think that none of this...
body:
the last scene with Crowley and Aziraphale? Beautiful. A masterpiece. Literal poetic cinema.

“I like to think that none of this would have worked out if you weren’t, at heart, a little bit of a nice person.”

“And if you weren’t, deep down, just enough of a bastard to be worth knowing.” The cadence of his tone has love dripping off his tounge, and Aziraphale’s smile has his beaming heart plain across his lips.

And then the smile Crowley gives Aziraphale as he says, “Cheers. To the world.”

And the absolute love and adoration in Aziraphale’s eyes as he says “to the world” as if “the world” were just a synonym for Crowley’s name, because he is in fact, Aziraphale’s world?

God. It may never be explicitly said, but these two’s overwhelming love for each other is breath taking.
